description: Jicama, also known as Mexican turnip or yam bean, is a root vegetable native to Mexico. It belongs to the legume family and is prized for its crisp texture and mildly sweet flavor. Jicama has a crunchy, white flesh and a thin brown skin that should be peeled before eating. It is commonly used in salads, salsas, and stir-fries, as well as eaten raw as a crunchy snack. Jicama is low in calories and rich in fiber, vitamin C, and other nutrients, making it a healthy addition to any diet.
varieties: Jicama, also known as Mexican turnip or yam bean, does not have as many varieties as other crops. However, there are some cultivars that vary slightly in shape, size, and taste. Common varieties of jicama include 'Mexican Red', 'Cachucha', and 'Mexican Cream'. These varieties generally produce large, round tubers with crisp, white flesh and a mildly sweet flavor.

sowingAndPlanting.sowingIndoorsDescription: Jicama is typically grown from seeds directly sown outdoors rather than started indoors. However, if you want to get a head start on the growing season, you can start seeds indoors in biodegradable pots or trays filled with potting mix. Plant seeds 1 inch deep and keep the soil consistently moist and warm (70-85°F). Transplant seedlings outdoors once the danger of frost has passed and the soil has warmed up.
sowingAndPlanting.sowingOutdoorsDescription: Jicama seeds should be sown directly outdoors once the soil has warmed up and all danger of frost has passed. Choose a sunny location with well-drained soil. Plant seeds 1 inch deep and space them 6-12 inches apart in rows spaced 12-24 inches apart. Keep the soil consistently moist until seedlings emerge.
sowingAndPlanting.season: Jicama should be planted in the spring after the danger of frost has passed and the soil has warmed up. It requires a long, warm growing season to produce tubers.

careAndMaintenance.growingDescription: Jicama prefers full sun and well-drained, sandy loam soil. It requires regular watering to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Mulch around plants to conserve moisture, suppress weeds, and maintain even soil temperature.
careAndMaintenance.wateringNeeds: Regular watering, aiming for 1-2 inches per week.
careAndMaintenance.soilFertility: Incorporate compost or well-aged manure into the soil before planting to improve fertility and soil structure. Side-dress jicama with a balanced fertilizer once it starts growing.
careAndMaintenance.pruningRequirements: Jicama plants do not require pruning.
careAndMaintenance.supportRequirements: Jicama plants typically do not require support.

harvestingAndStorage.timeToMaturity: Jicama typically matures and is ready for harvest 120-150 days after planting, depending on growing conditions.
harvestingAndStorage.storageRecommendations: Harvest jicama when the vines start to die back and the tubers reach a desirable size (usually 3-6 months after planting). Carefully dig up the tubers, being careful not to damage them. Wash the tubers thoroughly to remove any dirt or debris. Store harvested jicama in a cool, dry place with good air circulation. It can be stored for several weeks to several months.
harvestingAndStorage.harvestDescription: Harvest jicama by carefully digging up the tubers with a garden fork or shovel. Wash the tubers thoroughly before storing or using them.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Corn
goodCompanionPlants.description: Corn provides natural support for pole beans to climb, while beans fix nitrogen in the soil, benefiting the nitrogen-demanding jicama plants. Interplanting corn with jicama can improve soil fertility and promote healthier growth for both crops.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Cucumbers
goodCompanionPlants.description: Cucumbers have shallow roots and can be interplanted with jicama to help suppress weeds and conserve soil moisture. The two plants can coexist without competing for space, making them suitable companions in the garden.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Radishes
goodCompanionPlants.description: Radishes are fast-growing and can help break up compacted soil, making it easier for jicama roots to penetrate. Interplanting radishes with jicama can improve soil aeration, drainage, and overall plant health.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Sweet Potatoes
goodCompanionPlants.description: Sweet potatoes and jicama can be planted together as they have similar soil and cultural requirements. Interplanting them can maximize space in the garden and provide mutual benefits, such as weed suppression and improved soil health.

goodCompanionPlants.name: Lettuce
goodCompanionPlants.description: Lettuce can be grown near jicama as a living mulch to suppress weeds and conserve soil moisture. The shallow roots of lettuce and jicama complement each other, allowing them to coexist without competing for soil nutrients.

badCompanionPlants.name: Onions
badCompanionPlants.description: Onions and other alliums may inhibit the growth of jicama if planted too closely together. Some studies suggest that alliums release substances that can interfere with jicama growth and development.

badCompanionPlants.name: Garlic
badCompanionPlants.description: Similar to onions, garlic may have an inhibitory effect on jicama if planted too closely together. Planting garlic near jicama may result in reduced growth and yield for jicama crops.

badCompanionPlants.name: Brassicas
badCompanionPlants.description: Brassicas, such as cabbage, broccoli, and kale, may produce allelopathic compounds that inhibit the growth of nearby plants, including jicama. Planting brassicas near jicama may hinder jicama growth and development.

badCompanionPlants.name: Beans
badCompanionPlants.description: Beans may compete with jicama for space, water, and nutrients in the soil. Planting them too closely together may result in reduced growth and yield for both jicama and bean crops.

badCompanionPlants.name: Peas
badCompanionPlants.description: Peas have similar growth habits to beans and may compete with jicama for resources if planted too closely together. Planting peas near jicama may lead to overcrowding and reduced yields for both crops.

tipsAndTricks: Plant jicama in well-drained soil with full sun exposure.
Provide support for jicama vines, such as trellises or stakes.
Water jicama regularly, keeping the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged.
Mulch around the base of plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds.
Harvest jicama tubers when they reach a size suitable for consumption, typically 4 to 6 months after planting.
Rotate crops to prevent the buildup of pests and diseases in the soil.
Monitor plants regularly for signs of pests and diseases, and take appropriate action.

linksToAdditionalResources.title: Jicama: A Crunchy and Refreshing Vegetable
